title: Jaap Stam
text:
Jakob "Jaap" Stam (; born 17 July 1972) is a Dutch <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="manager">manager</a>, former head coach and former professional player. He is regarded as one of the best <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a>s of his generation.
Stam played for several European clubs including <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV Eindhoven</a>, <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a>, <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">Lazio</a>, <a href="A.C.%20Milan">Milan</a> and <a href="AFC%20Ajax">Ajax</a> before retiring in October 2007. As well as club trophies, he won several personal awards, including being voted the best defender in the <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">1998–99</a> and <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">1999–2000 UEFA Champions League</a>, as well as being included in three consecutive <a href="PFA%20Team%20of%20the%20Year">PFA Team of the Year</a> sides from 1999 to 2001. Stam played 67 international matches for the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a>, scoring three goals. He was in their squads for three <a href="UEFA%20European%20Championship">UEFA European Championship</a>s and the <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1998 FIFA World Cup</a>. 
After retiring as a player, Stam worked as a coach at <a href="PEC%20Zwolle">PEC Zwolle</a> and Ajax before making his managerial debut with <a href="Reading%20F.C.">Reading</a> in 2016. He later managed <a href="Feyenoord">Feyenoord</a> in 2019 and <a href="FC%20Cincinnati">FC Cincinnati</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>.
Club career.
Early career.
Born in <a href="Kampen%2C%20Overijssel">Kampen</a>, <a href="Overijssel">Overijssel</a>, Stam started his career with local amateur football club <a href="DOS%20Kampen">DOS Kampen</a>. On 15 August 1992, Stam made his professional debut for <a href="PEC%20Zwolle">FC Zwolle</a> in a 1–1 draw against <a href="Heracles%20Almelo">SC Heracles</a> in the <a href="Eerste%20Divisie">Eerste Divisie</a>. He became a first team regular right away and moved to <a href="Eredivisie">Eredivisie</a> club <a href="SC%20Cambuur">Cambuur Leeuwarden</a> for the following season, but relegated in his first season which brought him back into the Eerste Divisie. Two seasons at Cambuur earned him a transfer to Eredivisie club <a href="Willem%20II%20%28football%20club%29">Willem II</a>. At Willem II, he immediately impressed at the Eredivisie level, which meant his final breakthrough. A shock 1–0 home victory over <a href="AFC%20Ajax">Ajax</a> led to Stam's transfer to <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV Eindhoven</a> in the same season in which they eventually won the <a href="KNVB%20Cup">KNVB Cup</a>, his first professional trophy.
PSV.
Stam was a key player for PSV in the <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20Eredivisie">1996–97 season</a>, as the team won the Eredivisie league championship and the <a href="Johan%20Cruyff%20Shield">Johan Cruyff Shield</a>. Individually, Stam won the VVCS Footballer of the Year award.
In 1998, Stam became the then <a href="World%20football%20transfer%20record">most expensive</a> defender in history when <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> bought him for <a href="Pound%20sterling">£</a>10.6 million.
Manchester United.
Stam spent three seasons at Manchester United, during which time United won three <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> titles, one <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a>, the <a href="Intercontinental%20Cup%20%28football%29">Intercontinental Cup</a> and the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a>. He scored his only goal for the club in a 6–2 away victory against <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a>.
Early in the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20in%20English%20football">2001–02</a> season, Stam was controversially sold to <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">Lazio</a> in Italy after Manchester United manager <a href="Alex%20Ferguson">Sir Alex Ferguson</a> was reportedly upset by allegations Stam had made in his autobiography "Head to Head" about the club. Stam made numerous statements in the book about his views on opposing players, and notoriously alleged that Ferguson's approach to buy him was done without the permission of PSV. Later, <a href="Simon%20Kuper">Simon Kuper</a> reported that contrary to initial belief, Ferguson had noticed that Stam's tackling numbers were declining and simply assumed the defender was past his playing peak. <a href="Laurent%20Blanc">Laurent Blanc</a> was signed as his replacement.
In 2007, however, Ferguson described the decision to sell Stam as an error: "At the time he had just come back from an achilles injury and we thought he had just lost a little bit. We got the offer from Lazio, £16.5m for a centre back who was 29. It was an offer I couldn't refuse. But in playing terms it was a mistake. He is still playing for Ajax at a really good level." On the financial report, Manchester United announced the fee was £15.3 million; Lazio declared the fee was £16 million.
Lazio.
During his time with Lazio, Stam was found guilty of having the banned steroid <a href="nandrolone">nandrolone</a> in his system following a <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> game, and received a five-month ban, which was eventually reduced by a month after appeals. He was the second Lazio player suspended in 2001, after <a href="Fernando%20Couto">Fernando Couto</a>. 
In his last season at the club, he won the <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a>.
Milan.
Stam joined <a href="A.C.%20Milan">Milan</a> after <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202004">UEFA Euro 2004</a>. He reached his second Champions League final with the "Rossoneri" in <a href="2005%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">2005</a>, but was a runner-up after his team was defeated by <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> in a <a href="Penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">penalty shoot-out</a>.
Ajax.
On 30 January 2006, it was announced that he would return to the Eredivisie and play for Ajax, where he signed a two-year contract for a €2.5 million transfer fee. Stam was named team captain upon his arrival at the club. In his first season, he won both the Johan Cruyff Shield and the KNVB Cup; another Johan Cruyff Shield was added to his trophies at the start of the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20AFC%20Ajax%20season">2007–08 season</a>.
On 29 October 2007, Stam announced his retirement from professional football with immediate effect after playing six league games for Ajax in the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Eredivisie">2007–08 league</a> season. His final game was in a 0–0 draw against <a href="N.E.C.%20%28football%20club%29">NEC</a> on 20 October 2007.
International career.
Stam made his debut for <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">the Netherlands</a> on 24 April 1996 in a 1–0 friendly defeat to <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">Germany</a> in <a href="Rotterdam">Rotterdam</a>. He was not initially chosen for <a href="UEFA%20Euro%2096">UEFA Euro 96</a>, but was later added to the squad after an injury ruled out <a href="Frank%20de%20Boer">Frank de Boer</a>; he did not however make any appearances at the tournament. He scored his first goal on 6 September 1997 in a 3–1 home win over rivals Belgium in World Cup qualification. He was also an important player in the Dutch team that finished fourth in the <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1998 FIFA World Cup</a>.
During <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202000">UEFA Euro 2000</a>, he once again reached the semi-finals with the Dutch team, hosted in his home country and Belgium. Stam missed his attempt in the penalty shoot-out in the semi-finals, smashing the ball over the goal in a defeat against <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a>. He was not originally scheduled to take a penalty, but had to due to substitutions and fatigue among the Dutch.
Stam reached his third semi-finals in an international competition with his nation at <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202004">UEFA Euro 2004</a> in Portugal and retired from international football after the tournament. The reason cited for his international retirement was that he wanted to focus on his new team, Milan, as well as his family.
In total, he played 67 matches for the Netherlands, scoring three goals.
Playing style.
Stam played primarily as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Centre-back">centre-back</a>. He was known for possessing "a rare combination of speed, strength and ball-playing ability", as well as an excellent positional sense. Due to his wide range of skills, in his prime he was also capable of playing as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">full-back</a> on the right flank.
Post-playing career.
In October 2008, Stam returned to Manchester United as a scout for the club, responsible for most of South America.
Soccer Aid.
Stam has been involved with <a href="Soccer%20Aid">Soccer Aid</a>, which puts celebrities and football legends together in two teams (England and Rest of the World) for a charity game in aid of <a href="UNICEF">UNICEF</a>. Stam has appeared in five Soccer Aid matches 2008, 2012, 2014, 2016 and 2018.
Coaching and managerial career.
In 2009, Stam became an assistant coach for PEC Zwolle, and on 30 October was appointed caretaker manager. Following his stint with Zwolle, Stam penned a three-year contract with Ajax in 2013 as an assistant coach, and as defensive coach starting in the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Eredivisie">2013–14 Eredivisie</a> season. On 28 May 2014, Stam was revealed as one of the new managers of <a href="Jong%20Ajax">Jong Ajax</a>, the reserve team in the Eerste Divisie. He was joined by <a href="Andries%20Ulderink">Andries Ulderink</a> and they signed a contract beginning on 1 July 2014 and lasting until 30 June 2016.
Reading.
On 13 June 2016, Stam was appointed as manager of English <a href="EFL%20Championship">Championship</a> club <a href="Reading%20F.C.">Reading</a> on an initial two-year contract. He enjoyed a successful first season with the club, leading them to the Championship play-offs. On 4 July 2017, Stam signed a new two-year contract extension with Reading, keeping him at the club until 2019. On 21 March 2018, Reading announced that Stam had left the club with immediate effect following a run of one win in 18 league matches left the team 20th in the league table.
PEC Zwolle.
On 28 December 2018, Stam was appointed as the new manager of Eredivisie club PEC Zwolle on a year-and-a-half contract.
Feyenoord.
On 6 March 2019, Feyenoord announced that Stam would succeed <a href="Giovanni%20van%20Bronckhorst">Giovanni van Bronckhorst</a> as <a href="Feyenoord">Feyenoord</a>'s new manager. He signed a two-year contract, effective 1 June 2019. Following a 0–4 defeat to Ajax, Stam resigned on 28 October 2019, saying "I've thought about this for a long time. My final conclusion is that it's better for the club, the players and myself if I step aside."
FC Cincinnati.
On 21 May 2020, <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a> club <a href="FC%20Cincinnati">FC Cincinnati</a> announced that Stam would succeed interim manager <a href="Yoann%20Damet">Yoann Damet</a>. He signed a year-and-a-half contract. On 15 July, he won 1–0 on his debut against an <a href="Atlanta%20United%20FC">Atlanta United FC</a> side managed by his former international teammate <a href="Frank%20de%20Boer">Frank de Boer</a>.
Stam was dismissed on 27 September 2021, with Cincinnati second-from-bottom in the <a href="Eastern%20Conference%20%28MLS%29">Eastern Conference</a> having won four of 25 games.
Personal life.
Stam is a Protestant. He met his wife Ellis when he was 16, and they have two daughters and twin sons. His first daughter's birth was induced two weeks early, to come between the 1998 World Cup and pre-season training for Manchester United. When he played for Manchester United, he lived in <a href="Wilmslow">Wilmslow</a> in <a href="Cheshire">Cheshire</a>.
